definition: cow's piss, horse's ulcer (idiom); worthless nonsense/insignificant
surname Niu
ox/cow/bull/CL:條|条[tiao2],頭|头[tou2]/newton (abbr. for 牛頓|牛顿[niu2 dun4])/(slang) awesome
to urinate
horse/CL:匹[pi3]/horse or cavalry piece in Chinese chess/knight in Western chess
surname Ma/abbr. for Malaysia 馬來西亞|马来西亚[Ma3 lai2 xi1 ya4]
flourishing/prosperous/suddenly/abruptly
clay ox, wooden horse (idiom); shape without substance/worthless object
if it's plowing, ask the laborer (idiom); when managing a matter, consult the appropriate specialist
cow and famous steed at the same trough (idiom); fig. the common and the great are treated alike
lit. the heart of a sheep in the skin of a tiger (idiom)/fig. impressive in appearance but lacking in substance/braggart
lit. the old man lost his horse, but it all turned out for the best (idiom)/fig. a blessing in disguise/it's an ill wind that blows nobody any good
lit. the scholar buys a donkey (idiom); fig. long-winded verbiage that never gets to the point/idiom mocking scholastic pomposity
lit. to use a sacred tripod as cooking pot and jade as ordinary stone (idiom); fig. a waste of precious material/casting pearls before swine
Sima Xiangru is meticulous and Mei Gao is fast (idiom)/to each his good points
see 追本溯源[zhui1 ben3 su4 yuan2]
a black stallion or possibly a yellow mare (idiom); don't judge by outward appearance
neither fish nor fowl/resembling nothing on earth
to see the ox already cut up into joints (idiom); extremely skilled/able to see through the problem at one glance
to touch base matter and turn it to gold (idiom); fig. to turn crude writing into a literary gem
a thousand tries leads to one success (idiom, humble expr.); Even without any notable ability on my part, I may still get it right sometimes by good luck.
to call sth a cow or a horse (idiom); it doesn't matter what you call it/Insult me if you want, I don't care what you call me.
too many to count/very many/innumerable
